intro: Aquilegia viridiflora var. viridiflora, commonly known as the green-flowered columbine, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring basal leaves that are palmately lobed and often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces showy, spurred flowers in shades of blue, purple, and white, with five sepals that are reflexed backward. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant prefers moist, well-drained soils and partial to full shade, making it a suitable addition to woodland gardens.
